page.title: 10Tilly Whim Caves
page.content: The sea cliffs in our study area were quarried over 150 years ago for Portland Limestone. Tilly Whim caves are not natural caves, but old quarry workings. A whim was a crane that was used for lifting the stone from the quarry down into barges which then transported the stone to Swanage. Tilly was the name of one of the quarrymen. George Burt opened thw caves as a tourist attraction in 1887 and they remained so until 1977 when after safety inspection they were closed to the public. They now provide a habitat for bats. From the cliff path you can look down onto the ledges where the whim was sighted and marvel at the skill of the quarrymen.
